bioghist.p: Alfred Stillé (1813-1900) entered Yale College in 1828, and left after his sophomore year to attend the University of Pennsylvania. Stillé graduated with an A.B. degree in 1832 and a M.D. degree in 1836. Stillé completed his medical education in Paris under Pierre-Charles-Alexandre Louis. After his return from Europe, Stillé served as a resident physician at Pennsylvania Hospital from 1839 to 1841. In 1849, Stillé was appointed visiting physician at St. Joseph's Hospital and, from 1854 to 1859, as professor of the theory and practice of medicine at the medical department of Pennsylvania Medical College. In 1864 he became professor of theory and practice of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, a post he held until 1884. He was a founder and president of the Philadelphia Pathological Society, president of the Philadelphia County Medical Society, president of the College of Physicians (1883-1884) and a founder, first secretary, and president of the American Medical Association.

scopecontent.p: This is a small collection of correspondence between Dr. Alfred Stillé and Senator Henry W. Blair. The letters relate to alcohol and the temperance movement. The collection also includes a newspaper clipping on temperance medicine (medical treatment not involving the use of alcohol).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
